body:
Hi, 
I can' t really try I have don't have end key on my laptop, but `Fn+Right`(which should be end on os X) works for me but  `Fn+left` (home) bring to beginning of line, which is not symmetric.

Side question, `In qtconsole (1.7.0b2)` where did you get this number ? Current stable is `0.13.1`, dev is `0.14-dev`. Does Arch have a different packaging number ?

I'd consider end of line to be the expected behaviour for the end key. I
think it's a limitation of the terminal that it doesn't work like that
there.

Hmm. For me IPython the end key has always gone to the end of the command and I have gotten used to this behaviour.

There are a couple reasons why I prefer this behaviour over going to the end of the line:
1. Often, when I am making changes to a command it is to add new kwargs or modify the last parameter in a function call or loop.
2. For commands that are more than a few lines long, if you make home go to the beginning of the command and end go to the end of the command, then you can get to any line in the command by going to either home/end and moving the cursor forward/backward <= 50%. Otherwise you may have to do more work to make changes somewhere near the end of the command (move through >50% of the command manually).

Of course, the main reason I prefer this behaviour is probably just because I'm so used it it now. I'm sure I would be just as disoriented if the end key always went to the end of the line and then one day suddenly switched.

Well, in every 'proper' multiline editor, home and end go to the start/end
of the line. Typically, Ctrl+home & Ctrl+end go to the start/end of the
file. But the terminal doesn't really do multiline editing - it just treats
it as one line that happens to have some newlines in.

On 17 November 2012 17:45, Keith Hughitt notifications@github.com wrote:

> Hmm. For me IPython the end key has always gone to the end of the command
> and I have gotten used to this behaviour.
> 
> There are a couple reasons why I prefer this behaviour over going to the
> end of the line:
> 
>    1.
> 
>    Often, when I am making changes to a command it is to add new kwargs
>    or modify the last parameter in a function call or loop.
>    2.
> 
>    For commands that are more than a few lines long, if you make home go
>    to the beginning of the command and end go to the end of the command, then
>    you can get to any line in the command by going to either home/end and
>    moving the cursor forward/backward <= 50%. Otherwise you may have to do
>    more work to make changes somewhere near the end of the command (move
>    through >50% of the command manually).
> 
> Of course, the main reason I prefer this behaviour is probably just
> because I'm so used it it now. I'm sure I would be just as disoriented if
> the end key always went to the end of the line and then one day suddenly
> switched.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/2594#issuecomment-10476670.

In zsh, you can use home (or Ctrl-a) and end (or Ctrl-e) to go to the begging and ending the line.  So I guess it is the limitation of readline, not terminal, meaning that it is not impossible to support such editing in IPython terminal console.  If there is a Python library which can do that IPython can use it, I suppose.

Yes, that sounds quite plausible. I've had an eye for a while on pyrepl (
http://codespeak.net/pyrepl/ ), which PyPy also use for their interactive
shell, but I haven't got around to playing with it.

> In zsh, you can use home (or Ctrl-a) and end (or Ctrl-e) to go to the
> begging and ending the line. So I guess it is the limitation of readline,
> not terminal, meaning that it is not impossible to support such editing in
